headline: 7½-hour phone gap? Did Donald Trump channel Rose Mary Woods on Jan. 6?
author: EJ Montini
sentences:
McCarthy was asking Trump to publicly call off the rioters who were overrunning the Capitol and Trump supposedly said to him, “Well, Kevin, I guess these people are more upset about the election than you are.”
Those Nixon tapes were 'accidentally' erased
As you can imagine, the conversation didn’t go well from there.

That happened with the late-President Richard Nixon’s loyal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, was made to transcribe the ugly, incriminating taped phone calls of her boss, who was then mired in an investigation that would lead to his resignation as president.

White House documents turned over by the National Archives to the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 insurrection show no record of calls from 11:17 a.m. to 6:45 p.m. on the day of the Capitol attack, a gap of 7 hours and 37 minutes.

There are no more Goldwaters in the GOP
The select committee reached out to Minority Leader McCarthy and Republican Reps. Scott Perry and Jim Jordan to talk about Jan. 6, but they are not cooperating.
Arizona judge rules that 'law enforcement' is NOT a profession If the Constitution means anything, kick Rep. Gosar off the ballot Does Ducey really think cops in Alaska can help secure our border?
Nixon was forced to resign because there were a number of Republicans in Congress, including Arizona’s late-Sen. Barry Goldwater, who were willing to put country over party.
That’s how Trump skated through two impeachments and probably will skate again after whatever recommendations the select committee makes to the Justice Department.
So, why in the 11 pages of records noting calls is there a 7-plus hour gap, particularly when Trump was heavily on the phone earlier in the day and later?
But former national security adviser to Trump, John Bolton, told CBS News on Tuesday that he heard Trump use the phrase “burner phones” several times.
For example, there was a testy exchange confirmed by numerous Republican lawmakers that the president had with House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy.
Didn’t you just know that someday, something involving former President Donald Trump could accurately and legitimately be described as Nixon-esque?
Trump has said he’s never heard the phrase “burner phone,” and that he doesn’t know anything about untraceable disposable phones.
In the months since then many public reports have described phone conversations Trump had during that day.
During his time in the White House it was widely reported that Trump often avoided official phone lines.
He was known use his own private cellphones for official business and to borrow the phones of others.
Proving, once and for all, that the man they called “Tricky Dick” has nothing on The Donald.
It is eerily reminiscent of that 18½-minute gap in the Watergate tapes from the 1970s.
Woods claimed that she had erased a long, long section of a recording by accident.
They told Nixon he would be convicted in a Senate impeachment trial.
Hardly any country-over-party Republicans exist today.
So, was Trump channeling Rose Mary Woods on Jan. 6?

And the committee is unlikely to subpoena them.

Nixon relied on landlines.
Were those used on Jan. 6?
